field_edited_text.value:
The sponsors of this folder present to the motorist, fast scenic
bridge and ferry routes through sections replete in historic

and picturesque beauty.

Listed below are a few of the numerous places of interest that may be

visited enroute:

1—Havre de Grace, Maryland.—Originally called Susque-
hanna Lower Ferry. General Washington stopped here
many times: also site of the Susquehanna River Bridge,
adjudged the most beautiful large bridge built in the
. United States during 1940.
2—"Tudor Hall”. Birthplace of Edwin Booth and John Wilkes
Booth.
3—Birthplace of William Paca, signer of the Declaration of
Independence. R s 7
4—Baltimore, Maryland. Birthplace of the “Star Spangled
Banner” and seventh largest city in the United States,
third largest seoport in total waler borne commerce, wast
industrial center, manufacturing a wide variety of
products.
5—Annapolis, capital of Maryland. Untouched by restora-
tion Annapolis has been adjudged the finest example of
a colonial city in America. Particularly interesting to
visitors are: the United States Naval Academy (1845),
Chase House, Hammond Harwood House, St. John’s Col-
lege (1696), St. Anne’s Church (1699) are but a few of
them.,
6—Site of home and grave of Dr. Beanes whose arrest by
the British in 1814 was the cause of.Francis Scott Key
writing the “Star Spangled Banner”. :
7—"Mount Airy”. The home of Benedict Calvert whose
daughter married Washington’'s stepson. ;
8—"De La Brooke Manor”. Surveyed in 1650 for Robert
Brooke, Commander of Charles County.
9—The birthplace of Roger Brooke Taney., Chief Justice of
the United States, 1836-64.
10—"The Cliffs of Calvert”. One of the most picturesque spots
in Maryland.
11—"Dr. Mudd’'s House”. Home of Dr. Mudd, who set the
broken leg of John Wilkes Booth.
12—"La Grange”, the home of Dr. James Craik, Washington’s
lifelong friend and physician.
13—"Samuel Cox's Fdarm"”, where John Wilkes Booth and his
accomplice hid for several days.
14—"Laidlow’s Ferry”. Washington crossed here many times
on his way to Williamsburg. Practically the present site
of the Potomac River Bridge.
15—Wakefield, Virginia. Birthplace of George Washington.
Now a National Monument, the estate is under the super-
vision of the National Parks.
16—Saint Mary's City, Maryland. Siter of Maryland's pro-
vincial government for more than sixty years, after which
the capitol was moved to Annapolis in 1695. There now
stands on the original site a replica of the original
State House, made from brick brought over from England.
17—Richmond, Virginia. A typical city of the South and its
traditions. The capitol of Virginia and its largest city,
in and near this city are some of the country’s most noted
shrines.
18—Petersburg, Va. In and around this city ebbed and
flowed the tide of battle in the last days of the great
fratricidal strife, in 1865. Many fine monuments have been
erected on the scenes of many of the engagements and
this battlefield is one of the national shrines. f

19—Jamestown, Va. It was here in May 1607, that the Susan
Constant, Goodspeed and Discovery discharged their
cargoes of human freight and supplies, which resulted in
the first permanent English settlement in America.

20—Williamsburg, Va. This historic city, the colonial capitol
of Virginia, has been restored to its original appearance.
Among the many historic buildings that may be seen here
are the Governor’s Palace and extensive forry 1 gardens,
the capitol and the Raleigh Tavern. Here too stands the
Wren Building, oldest academic structure in English
America. The College of William and Mary was esiab-
liched in 1693,

21—Gloucester, Va. The very quaint Courthouse here was
erected in 1766. Here is buried Mildred Warner the grand-
mother of General Washington. Also near here is the
place where the Indian Princess, Pocahontas, rescued
Captain John Smith.

22—Yorktown, Va. The object of the siege which ended the
American Revolution with the surrender of Cornwallis to
Washington, October 19, 1781.

23—"Mariner’s Museum”. Situated in an extensive park and
game sanctuary. Is educational in purpose, world-wide
in scope, aiming to display maritime accomplishments
of all times and every nation.

24—Chestertown, Md. The seat of Washington College among
the oldest in the country, founded in 1782. Also the birth-
place of Charles Willson Peale, one of America’s most
famous artists.

25—Matapeake, Md. Site of the Eastern terminus of the
Annapolis Ferry. Here on “Kent Island” William Claiborne
established a trading post settlement and fort in 1631.

26—"Bloomingdale”, an interesting example of Georgian
architecture. This house has a two-story hexagonul por-
tico, the only one of its kind in Maryland. The oldest
part of Bloomingdale is the litile kitchen wing built in
1660.

27—"Wye Oak”, the largest white oak in America. This
tree over 400 years old was probably just a hearty
sapling when Columbus discovered America.

28—Near Easton, Md., are located many famous Colonial
homes such as: “Wye House” home of the Lloyd family
for over 200 years, here, lived Mary Taylor Lloyd, wife
of Francis Scott Key. “The Mannour of Ratcliffe”, Col-
onial home of the Holliday Family. Also “Old Friends
Meeting House”, visited by William Penn in 1682, the
cldest frame meeting house in America.

29—OId “Trinity Church”, built prior to 1670, located on
Church Creek a few miles below Cambridge. This place
of worship ranks as one of the most historic churches in
Maryland.

30—Birthplace of Samuel Chase, a signer of the Declaration
of Independence.

31—Ocean City, Md. The very name of Ocean City brings a
thrill to thousands of young and old, who have dis-
covered the countless advantages and delights offered
by this picturesque little city overlooking the broad
Atlantic,





To Du Bois To Pottsville
